our pneumatics code is not working. the compressor doesn’t run at all when the robot’s enabled, and there’re no errors from driverstation when we’re running the robot.

intake subsystem (intakeSol is the double solenoid):
IntakeSubsystem.java (1.9 KB)

Robot.java:
Robot.java (4.6 KB)

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T17:44:07.593Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":97.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431306,"topic_slug":"need-help-on-pneumatics-code","display_username":"Hannah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/uploads/short-url/nM0mSReINL0oaR2556crtgQPblo.java","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"/uploads/short-url/jFB6irEA07JbJglXvMbVFqr1hBM.java","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56307,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/need-help-on-pneumatics-code/431306/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3170484,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T18:02:38.644Z","cooked":"

You’re creating a solenoid, which ought to be enough to make the compressor run. (I assume you’re using the Rev Pneumatic Hub.) What do the status lights show?

  public static DriveSubsystem DriveSubsystem = new DriveSubsystem();
  public static ArmSubsystem ArmSubsystem = new ArmSubsystem();
  public static IntakeSubsystem IntakeSubsystem = new IntakeSubsystem();

You shouldn’t be making your subsystems static on RobotContainer. You also shouldn’t be giving your member variables the same name as the class.

I notice when you construct a DoubleSolenoid object you do not have an ID associated to the PCM module. This could be the reason your compressor will not turn on as after looking at the code, it appears that the default is 1.

intakeSol = new DoubleSolenoid(PneumaticsModuleType.REVPH, 1, 0);

are these the IDs that you’re talking about? we do have them in the subsystem

Here is an example from our code

    DoubleSolenoid extender = new DoubleSolenoid(60,PneumaticsModuleType.REVPH, 0, 1);

The first number is the CAN ID of our PCM module.

I recommend that you do not change the CAN id of your PCM/PH from the default.

I was really asking about all the status lights, not just the one labelled “status”. What about the compressor light?

Our team personally did it for logistical purposes. Anyway, I would check what the CAN ID of your PCM is though it might not be the default.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T18:34:30.460Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":63,"readers_count":62,"score":22.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431306,"topic_slug":"need-help-on-pneumatics-code","display_username":"Elijah Beard","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38743,"username":"bovlb","name":"Gavin Matthews","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5402 Programming M̶e̶n̶t̶o̶r̶ Advisor"},"post_url":"/t/need-help-on-pneumatics-code/431306/9","custom_user_title":"5402 Programming M̶e̶n̶t̶o̶r̶ Advisor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3170565,"name":"Hannah","username":"hannahL2323","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/8e8cbc/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T18:50:27.518Z","cooked":"

thank you for the advice. we’ll try including this in our code

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T18:50:27.518Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":57,"readers_count":56,"score":21.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":431306,"topic_slug":"need-help-on-pneumatics-code","display_username":"Hannah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":56380,"username":"ebear11","name":"Elijah Beard","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/439d5e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56307,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/need-help-on-pneumatics-code/431306/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3170596,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T19:22:38.152Z","cooked":"

Why do you make this recommendation? I think I saw the same recommendation on the WPILib docs. Is it solely so you don’t forget that you’ve changed it? Given that CAN prioritizes messages from low IDs (unless I’m misunderstanding how CAN arbirtration works for FRC devices) , it may be desirable to change the PCM’s ID to be higher than more critical motor controllers.

I would second checking the CAN ID of your pneumatics hub. We spent a stupid amount of time debugging that this season.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T19:22:38.152Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":52,"readers_count":51,"score":15.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":431306,"topic_slug":"need-help-on-pneumatics-code","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38743,"username":"bovlb","name":"Gavin Matthews","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/need-help-on-pneumatics-code/431306/11","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3170598,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T19:24:15.373Z","cooked":"
ebear11:

for logistical purposes

I’m curious what the logistical reasons are.

If it’s to avoid ID conflicts (i.e. so you can use 1 for a SparkMax ID), thats a very common misconception. The true ID on the wire incorporates both a device type and the ID you set, so you can have many devices with the same ID so long as theyre dofferent types.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2023-03-22T19:24:15.373Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":51,"readers_count":50,"score":10.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431306,"topic_slug":"need-help-on-pneumatics-code","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/need-help-on-pneumatics-code/431306/12","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3170631,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T20:00:36.649Z","cooked":"
Max_Morehead:

Why do you make this recommendation?

It means you can use the provided constants, and you don’t spend time debugging whether you have the right CAN id. It also reduces the chance that some piece of code somewhere is making assumptions that you’re using the default.

Max_Morehead:

Given that CAN prioritizes messages from low IDs … it may be desirable to change the PCM’s ID to be higher than more critical motor controllers.

The FRC CAN bus arbitration id is made up of a number of fields. I could be wrong, but I’m not convinced that reassigning the Device Number portion makes much difference in practice.

One thing that was incredibly helpful in our debugging was the compressor test mode. You can hold down the mode button for 7 seconds on your pneumatics hub and that should activate the compressor. That should rule out any wiring issues. Also can you confirm you have a pressure switch or analog pressure sensor attached to the pnuematics hub? Does the compressor run when you short the pressure switch terminals (assuming you’re using the switch)?

We wrote a guide about pnuematics and some of the really common troubleshooting steps here 5.6 Pneumatic Troubleshooting :: FRC Zero

I second the recommendations not to change the PCH/PCM can id from 0. This always breaks something it seems like.

To your last reply you said " I don’t think we have a pressure sensor attached" but every system has at least a digital pressure switch on the PCM or on the PCH you have both digital and analog as an option but one is required to make sure the tanks don’t overfill.

The pressure switch won’t return a psi scale but will signal if the compressor is safe to run. It is just a switch so while this isn’t the best safety advice you can bypass the pressure switch to force the compressor to run. This is a process inspectors will commonly do at Competition to ensure that the overflow valve is working properly.

If you take a screwdriver end (just the metal part) and put it between the two posts on the pressure switch with everything else correct the compressor should kick on. The pressure switch is Normally Open so when you close the circuit with the screwdriver it will make the PCM/PCH think the pressure is below the low psi limit and therefore start the compressor. This isn’t a long term answer and you should only do this long enough to confirm it’s working unless you are 100% sure your pressure relief system is tuned properly

This thread talks about bypassing the switch on the PCM to tune the overflow valve Calibrating Pneumatic System

If you don’t have a pressure sensor attached the the pneumatics hub, the compressor won’t run. The pressure sensor’s purpose is the make sure you don’t exceed the 120 PSI limit imposed by the rules (and the limit to which your pneumatic components must be rated to operate safely).
